questions.text: Allodynia is _____

choices.text: Augmented response to a stimulus that is usually painful
Pain evoked by an ordinary, usually painless stimulus
Abnormal unpleasant sensation, either spontaneous or evoked
Increased sensory experience with a stimulus

questions.solution:
• Allodynia is the pain evoked by an ordinary, usually painless (innocuous) stimulus such as rubbing or touching. It can occur in injuries to the spinal cord and after a thalamocortical stroke. It is also associated with complex regional pain syndromes (CRPS), multiple sclerosis, migraine, etc.
  • Hyperalgesia is the augmented response to a stimulus that is usually painful (noxious stimulus). It can also accompany spinal cord injuries and CRPS.
  • Dysesthesia is an abnormal, unpleasant sensation, either spontaneous or evoked. For example, when pressure causes burning pain. This is not to be confused with paresthesia, which is a abnormal but not unpleasant sensation, either spontaneous or evoked. For example, when rubbing gently gives the sensation of pressure.
  • Increased sensory experience with a stimulus is called hyperesthesia.

questions.text: The strongest association of essential mixed cryoglobulinemia (EMC) is with hepatitis ___ infection
questions.solution:
Hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection has the strongest association with essential mixed cryoglobulinemia (EMC), but it has been also linked with hepatitis A and B.

EMC is a systemic vasculitis, characterized by palpable purpura, arthralgias and weakness. Chronic liver disease and membrano-proliferative glomerular nephritis is usually associated with this syndrome in HCV infection.

Other Extrahepatic Manifestations of Viral Hepatitis:

  • Serum-like sickness syndrome – HBV and HCV infection
  • Polyarteritis nodosa – HBV
  • Membrano-proliferative glomerular nephritis – HBV and HCV (with EMC)
  • Papular acrodermatitis – HBV
  • Pancreatitis – HAV

questions.text: Nasal polyps are commonly associated with:
questions.solution:
Nasal polyps are associated with intrinsic asthma.

Intrinsic asthma is characterized by the presence of asthma with negative skin prick tests for common antigens. The association of nasal polyps with asthma is described by Samter’s triad (intrinsic asthma + aspirin hypersensitivity + nasal polyposis). Asthma is usually severe, persistent, and adult-onset.

Other options:

Option B: Brittle asthma refers to a severe variant of asthma where patients have very serious and often, life-threatening attacks despite appropriate therapy.

Option C: Extrinsic asthma is also referred to as atopic asthma. It is allergen mediated.

Option D: Exercise-induced asthma is airway narrowing due to strenuous physical activity. Symptoms typically start after the exercise has ended and last for around 30 minutes.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions are not at risk for pituitary apoplexy?
questions.solution:
Pituitary apoplexy does not occur in hyperthyroidism. It is a rare endocrine emergency which can occur due to haemorrhage or infarction of the pituitary gland. It may occur as a result of the following conditions:

  • Pituitary adenoma (spontaneous)
  • Sheehan syndrome
  • Acute shock
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Hypertension
  • Sickle cell anemia

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerves is predominantly involved in most cases of Ramsay Hunt syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ramsay Hunt Syndrome

  • Herpes zoster reactivation in the geniculate ganglion is the cause of this condition. It is also caused geniculate herpes zoster.
  • In most patients with Ramsay Hunt syndrome, there is involvement of the trunk of the facial nerve, which results in severe facial palsy.
  • Vesicular eruptions are commonly seen in the external auditory canal and in other parts.
  • Often, the 8th nerve is also involved, which causes hearing loss and vertigo.
  • Treatment is usually symptomatic and the return of function of the facial nerve is usually less than Bell’s palsy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best biomarker for lobar pneumonia?
questions.solution:
The best biomarker for lobar pneumonia is procalcitonin. 

The most commonly used biomarkers of severe inflammation are C-reactive protein (CRP) and procalcitonin (PCT). Levels of these acute phase reactants increase in the presence of bacterial pathogens. PCT testing distinguishes between bacterial (mostly lobar pneumonia) and viral infection to decide the need for antibacterial therapy or discontinuation of treatment.

CRP, fibrinogen, and serum amyloid A are other acute phase reactants.

questions.text: Palinopsia, simultanagnosia and oculomotor apraxia are entities of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Balint’s Syndrome:

  • The components involved in Balint’s syndrome include:
    1. Palinopsia: Persistence of a visual image despite changing gaze.
    2. Simultanagnosia (asimultanagnosia or simultagnosia): Inability to synthesize the entire image, or inability to perceive more than one item at a time.
    3. Oculomotor apraxia: Psychic paralysis of gaze or difficulty in changing the direction of gaze in presence of normal muscle function.
    4. Optic ataxia: Inco-ordination of movements of extremities under visual guidance and control, like inability in reaching for an object.
  • A variety of pathologies is said to cause this condition including neurodegenerative conditions, progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy and malignancies.
  • It usually also results from bilateral watershed infarcts, generally between the distal posterior and middle cerebral arterial territories.

Anton’s Syndrome:

  • It occurs due to bilateral infarction in the posterior cerebral arteries. It leads to cortical blindness - which the patient is usually unaware of or they deny it - and confabulations.

Parinaud’s Syndrome:

  • The site of lesion in this condition is the dorsal midbrain.
  • It consists of impaired vertical gaze (upgaze pareisis), convergence-retraction nystagmus, lid retraction (Collier’s sign) and pupillary light-near dissociation (pupillary areflexia).

Weber’s Syndrome:

  • Infarctions in the distribution of the penetrating branches of the posterior cerebral artery (PCA), which affects the cerebral peduncle and damages the III cranial nerve and pyramidal fibres.
  • Its manifestations include contralateral hemiplegia of the face, arm and legs and ipsilateral oculomotor paresis.

questions.text: A factory worker presents to the clinic with fever, tiredness, and a chronic dry cough. He says his symptoms are worst on the first day of the week, improve by the end of the week, and are almost non-existent over the weekends. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above characteristic pattern of symptoms is called Monday fever or Monday chest tightness and is due to byssinosis. 

Byssinosis is seen commonly in cotton factory workers due to cotton dust exposure. It is also caused due to flax, hemp, and jute dust.

It is due to occupational hypersensitivity reaction with symptoms occurring (or recurring) on the first day of the workweek and diminishing by the weekend due to development of tolerance.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the condition shown in the image below?

choices.text: Hypernatremia is a major cause of delayed neurologic deficits in this condition
Sensitivity of a CT scan is best within 96 hours
The Hunt-Hess scale can be used for the grading of this condition
Giant aneurysms are those greater than 3.5 cm

questions.solution:
The non-contrast CT image above shows a subarachnoid hemorrhage (marked with an arrow) with blood filling the subarachnoid cisterns bilaterally and into the Sylvian fissure.

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH):

  • Scales used for SAH grading are the Hunt-Hess scale and the World Federation of Neurosurgical Societies classification.
  • Most common causes of SAH are head trauma and rupture of a saccular aneurysm.
  • Giant aneurysms are those which are >2.5cm.
  • Characteristic clinical feature is the presence of a sudden onset, severe headache which the patient often describes as ‘the worst headache of their life’.
  • The four major causes of delayed neurologic deficits in SAH are rerupture of an aneurysm, hydrocephalus, vasospasm, and hyponatremia.
  • The gold standard of diagnosing SAH is a non-contrast CT scan which has a high sensitivity up to 72 hours. If a CT scan is negative, yet there is high suspicion of an SAH, then a lumbar puncture (LP) is to be done to check for xanthochromia, which is detectable from 2 hours after hemorrhage and lasts several weeks. If both CT and LP are negative, then a CT angiography can be done to search for the cause.

Note: The Modified Fisher scale is a method for grading SAH seen on non-contrast CT. The Hunt and Hess scale describes the severity of SAH and is used as a predictor of survival.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents to the clinic with easy fatiguability and weight loss. After a detailed workup, he is diagnosed with chronic myeloid leukemia. What is the initial treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The initial treatment of choice in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) is tyrosine kinase inhibitors. These include imatinib, nilotinib, dasatinib, bosutinib, and ponatinib.

Allogeneic stem cell transplant is considered in patients who are negative for Philadelphia chromosome, or who are non-responsive to the tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used in the prophylactic management of migraine?
questions.solution:
Drugs that have not shown benefit in prophylaxis of migraine: Verapamil (a calcium channel blocker), nimodipine, clonidine, fluoxetine (an SSRI).

Drugs used for prophylaxis of migraine:

  • Beta blockers: Propranolol, metoprolol, timolol, atenolol
  • Antidepressants: Amitriptyline, nortriptyline, imipramine
  • Anticonvulsants: Valproate, topiramate
  • Serotonin antagonist: Methysergide
  • Angiotensin II receptor blocker: Candesartan
  • Angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor: Lisinopril
  • Calcium channel blockers: Flunarizine

Onabotulinum toxin type A is used in prevention of chronic migraine

questions.text: Which of the following is an unlikely complication in patients with bronchiectasis?
questions.solution:
Lung cancer is not a known complication of bronchiectasis.

Complications of bronchiectasis include:

  • Massive hemoptysis 
  • Empyema and lung abscess
  • Respiratory failure
  • Pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale
  • Secondary amyloidosis (AA type)

Chronic and recurrent infections lead to secondary amyloidosis (AA type) and involve the kidneys.

questions.text: A 45-year old patient with suspected familial Alzheimer’s disease (AD) have genes called Presenilins which are found in the chromosomes -
questions.solution:
Familial Alzheimer's disease are predisposed to gene mutations in the Presenilin 1 (PSEN-1) gene on chromosome 14 and Presenilin 2 (PSEN-2) gene on chromosome 1. 

Genetic Considerations of Alzheimer’s disease (AD):

  • The APP gene on chromosome 21 is associated with AD in adult Down’s syndrome (trisomy 21) and also with early-age-of-onset familial AD (FAD).
  • Presenilins:
Presenilin-1 (PS-1) Presenilin-2 (PS-2)
Found on chromosome 14. Found on chromosome 1.
Mutations here cause earlier onset (mean of 45 years) and rapidly progressive type of AD, with shorter course (6-7 years). Mean onset of AD due to mutations here is 53 years, with mean duration being 11 years.
More common Less common
  • The ApoE gene on chromosome 19 is associated with the pathogenesis of AD. The ApoE4 allele is the single most important biological marker and genetic risk factor for AD.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man underwent emergency surgery following a road traffic accident. The surgery was performed under general anesthesia. Two days later, he developed features of respiratory failure. Which of the following types is likely to be present in him?
questions.solution:
The features of respiratory failure in the perioperative period of this patient is most likely due to lung atelectasis. Type 3 respiratory failure is most likely to be present in him.

Type 3 respiratory failure is also known as perioperative respiratory failure.

After general anesthesia, there is a decrease in functional residual capacity due to a reduction in muscular tone. This leads to airway closure and the collapse of the dependent lung units.

Atelectasis can be treated by frequent changes in position, chest physiotherapy, upright positioning, and control of incisional and abdominal pain. Non-invasive positive-pressure ventilation may also be used to reverse regional atelectasis.

questions.text: What is the most common site of gastric adenocarcinoma in the Asian population?
questions.solution:
The most common site of gastric adenocarcinoma in the Asian population is the antrum. This is because H. pylori infections are relatively more prevalent in Asian countries and are associated with carcinoma of the body and distal stomach than the proximal stomach.

However, in western countries, the proximal stomach is the most common site. This is attributed to a lesser prevalence of untreated H.pylori infections and a greater burden of chronic GERD and obesity in western countries.

Most common site of diffuse variety of Ca. Stomach : Fundus

Most common site of Gastric lymphoma : Antrum

Most common site of Burkitt’s lymphoma/EBV : Cardia / Body

questions.text: Which of the following immunologic diseases is the most common cause of chorea?
questions.solution:
• In addition to being the most common immunologic disorder that causes chorea, systemic lupus erythematosus is also the most common systemic disorder causing chorea.
  • Other immunologic disorders that cause chorea are Behcet’s syndrome, Sjogren’s syndrome, antiphospholipid antibody syndrome, etc.
  • Other systemic causes of chorea include thyrotoxicosis, HIV disease and polycythemia rubra vera.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions predominantly involve the upper lobe of the lung?
questions.solution:
Ankylosing spondylitis predominantly involves the upper lobe of the lung leading to pulmonary fibrosis.

Rheumatoid arthritis, scleroderma, and asbestosis predominantly involve the lower lobes of the lungs.

  • Histiocytosis X (LCH)
  • Ankylosing spondylitis, ABPA
  • Radiation
  • Tuberculosis
  • Sarcoidosis

Lower lobes - RAIDS

  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Asbestosis
  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) and non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
  • Drugs: bleomycin, busulfan, amiodarone, methotrexate, nitrofurantoin
  • Scleroderma

questions.text: The auto-antibody that is associated with myasthenia gravis, from the following, is _______

choices.text: Anti-low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LPR4) antibody

questions.solution:
One of the auto-antibodies in myasthenia gravis is anti-low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LPR4) antibodies

 

Related Pearl: Auto antibodies in a few disorders

Auto-antibodies in myasthenia gravis:

i) Anti-acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies

ii) Anti-muscle-specific kinase (MuSK) antibodies

iii) Anti-low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LRP4) antibodies

Anti-C1q antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and membrane proliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN). 

Anti-Smith antibodies (Anti-Sm) are associated with SLE.

Anti-lysosome associated membrane protein-2 (LAMP-2) antibodies are associated with certain types of vasculitis.

questions.text: An elderly woman presents with breathlessness on exertion. On auscultation, bilateral basal rales are heard. A chest CT is done and is shown below. Which of the following is likely to be increased in her?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the honeycomb pattern of lung parenchyma due to interstitial fibrosis is suggestive of interstitial lung disease (ILD). The alveolar-arterial gradient (PAO2-PaO2) is increased in ILD. It is a restrictive lung disease. 

In ILD, the alveolar-capillary bed is damaged and thus there is a decrease in diffusion capacity. Therefore, while the PAO2 (Alveolar O2) remains normal, the PaO2 (arterial) decreases, and the alveolar-arterial difference increases.

questions.text: In anterior spinal artery syndrome, which of the following is spared?
questions.solution:
In anterior spinal artery syndrome, the posterior columns are spared. Hence, vibration sense and proprioception are spared.

Anterior spinal artery syndrome involves the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord, affecting the corticospinal and spinothalamic tracts. Features of this syndrome are paralysis and sensory impairments below the level of the lesion, which include impairment of pain and temperature sensation. Vibration sense and proprioception are spared. Autonomic control is also compromised, which leads to sexual, bladder and bowel dysfunction.

questions.text: The diagnostic test for achalasia considered to be the most sensitive is _______
questions.solution:
Diagnosis of Achalasia

  • Manometry is considered the most sensitive as it identifies early disease before esophageal dilatation and food retention
  • Diagnosis of achalasia can be done by barium swallow x-ray and/or esophageal manometry
  • Endoscopy has little use except for ruling out pseudoachalasia
  • The diagnostic criteria for achalasia with manometry are impaired lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation and absent peristalsis

Pseudoachalasia is an achalasia-like dilatation in the esophagus secondary to causes other than primary denervation like malignancies, etc. Manometry is of negligible value in differentiating achalasia and pseudoachalasia but radiographic and endoscopic evaluation can be done.

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

questions.text: A 33-year-old man collapses during a family vacation. At the hospital, blood pressure is found to be 86/52 mm Hg, and random blood sugar is 49 mg/dl. His wife says that he has been on treatment for Addison's disease for two years but had forgotten to pack his medication for the trip. What is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of an adrenal crisis triggered by missed medication. In this patient who is a known case of adrenal insufficiency, IV hydrocortisone is the drug of choice.

However, in patients with newly diagnosed adrenal insufficiency, dexamethasone is used for the treatment of adrenal crisis. This is because dexamethasone is not measured in cortisol assays and would not interfere with the diagnostic tests, whereas hydrocortisone interferes with cortisol assays.

Acute adrenal insufficiency requires the immediate initiation of the following therapeutic strategies:

  • Rehydration - saline infusion at an initial rate of 1 L/h with continuous cardiac monitoring.
  • Glucocorticoid replacement - bolus injection of 100 mg hydrocortisone, followed by the maintenance dose of 100–200 mg over 24h.
  • Mineralocorticoid replacement - initiated once the daily hydrocortisone dose has been reduced to <50 mg as higher doses of hydrocortisone have sufficient mineralocorticoid action.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding lung cancer?

choices.text: It is the most common cancer in Indian men
Tobacco smoking is the most common cause
Adenocarcinoma is the most common histologic  type
It is the most common cause of cancer death

questions.solution:
The most common cancer seen in Indian men is lip and oral cavity cancer, not lung cancer.

Most common cancer:

  • In men globally- Lung cancer
  • In Indian men- Lip and oral cavity cancer
  • In women globally- Breast cancer
  • In Indian women- Breast cancer

Tobacco smoking is a primary cause of the development of lung cancer. It increases 10 fold greater risk of developing lung cancer compared to those who have never smoked.

It is the most common cause of cancer death.

Lung cancer awareness month is observed throughout November annually to raise awareness about risk reduction and treatment options. There is a lack of knowledge on lung cancer among people. It is an effort to improve outcomes for lung cancer patients across the world.

Related Pearl: Incidence of lung cancer according to histology

questions.text: Which of the following is not a rationale for follow-up in celiac disease?

choices.text: Adverse effects on the quality of life
Increased risk of immune system compromise and infections

questions.solution:
It is a common misconception that patients with celiac disease require limited follow-up as it can be treated with diet. Celiac disease is a significant condition with limited treatment adherence and it has adverse effects on the quality of life, nutrition and metabolic indices. Celiac disease carries an increased risk of malignancy like lymphoma. Other complications of celiac disease that justify regular follow-ups are intestinal ulceration, refractory sprue and collagenous sprue.

There is no evidence that celiac disease causes an increased risk of infections or immune system compromise, although increased frequency of infections in early life (infancy) is associated with the development of celiac disease.

questions.text: You can advise any of the following tests for screening of a patient suspected to be having Cushing's syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Determination of plasma ACTH levels is not advised as a screening test for a patient with Cushing's syndrome.

Plasma ACTH determination is done to distinguish between ACTH-dependent and independent causes. It is done after the screening or confirmation of Cushing's syndrome.

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man visits the OPD requesting medications to quit smoking; he has a history of seizures. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
Varenicline is the drug of choice for smoking cessation in the above scenario. First-line pharmacologic therapies for smoking cessation include nicotine replacement therapy (NRT), varenicline, and bupropion.  

Other options: 

  • Bupropion decreases seizure threshold and should be avoided in patients with a history of seizures.
  • Clonidine is considered to be a second-line drug for smoking cessation because of its prominent side-effects like postural hypotension, drowsiness, and dry mouth. USFDA considers the use of clonidine for tobacco cessation to be an “off-label” indication. It has limited efficacy in smoking cessation.
  • Nortriptyline is a second-line therapy that has shown moderate efficacy in aiding smoking cessation for individuals who cannot use a first-line agent or who need an adjunct to first-line therapy.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient is being evaluated for recurrent episodes of palpitations, headaches, and profuse sweating. He was found to have elevated blood pressure readings on multiple occasions over the past 2 months. Which of the following tests has the highest sensitivity and specificity for the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of pheochromocytoma. The measurement of 24-hour urinary fractionated metanephrines has both the highest specificity and sensitivity in the diagnosis of this condition.

  24-hour urinary fractionated metanephrines Plasma fractionated metanephrines
Sensitivity 98% 96-100%
Specificity 98% 85-89%
False positives Very rare Can occur due to drugs like levodopa, TCAs, α-blockers, β-blockers, diuretics
Procedure Collection of samples over 24 hours may be cumbersome Requires only a single blood sample. May be preferred in children.
Uses Preferred first-line test as it is highly specific

Reserved for patients with a high index of suspicion like:

  • Family history
  • Genetic syndromes like MEN2
  • Prior history of pheochromocytoma

Imaging modalities like CT and MRI have a sensitivity of around 98-100% and specificity of 70%.

questions.text: Which of the following has been linked to the development of irritable bowel syndrome?
questions.solution:
Pathophysiology of Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)

Although poorly understood, the following have been linked to the development of IBS:

  • Gastrointestinal motor abnormalities
  • Visceral hypersensitivity, peripheral and central sensitization, endogenous pain modulation
  • The stress-response system including the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis, corticotrophin-releasing factor (CRF), and the autonomic nervous system
  • Early adverse life events (EALs) like physical abuse, sexual abuse and other psychological stress factors including other conditions like vertebral deformities
  • Immune activation and mucosal inflammation
  • Post-infectious IBS
  • Altered gut flora
  • Abnormal serotonin pathway
  • Genetics
  • Bile acid processing

IBS is a functional gastrointestinal disorder (FGID)that is characterized by abdominal pain with alterations in stool form and/or frequency.

Rome criteria is used for diagnosis of IBS.

Related Pearl: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)
  • Associated with a change in stool frequency
  • Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with onset of some symptoms at least 6 months before diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a prehepatic cause of portal hypertension?
questions.solution:

  • Portal vein thrombosis
  • Splenic vein thrombosis
  • Massive splenomegaly (Banti’s syndrome)

  • Presinusoidal: Schistosomiasis, congential hepatic fibrosis
  • Sinusoidal: Cirrhosis, alcoholic hepatitis
  • Postsinusoidal: Venoocclusive disease

  • Budd-Chiari syndrome
  • Inferior vena caval webs
  • Cardiac causes – Restrictive cardiomyopathy, constrictive pericarditis, severe congestive heart failure

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain and swelling in his scrotum and was diagnosed to have testicular carcinoma. There is a history of MEN syndrome running in his family. Which of the following conditions is he likely to have?
questions.solution:
This patient is likely to have MEN4 syndrome as reproductive organ tumors are a characteristic feature of this condition.

It is associated with CDKN1B gene on chromosome 12.

  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

questions.text: Identify the pathology in the gall bladder shown in the image

choices.text: Multiple cholesterol stones with biliary sludge

questions.solution:
The above image shows a gall bladder with changes as seen in cholesterolosis. There is abnormal deposition of lipid within the macrophages of the lamina propria of the gall bladder wall.

The diffuse yellow specks give the gall bladder a strawberry appearance and thus it is called strawberry gall bladder. Cholesterol polyps (as seen in the image) are common in this condition and sometimes cholesterol stones are also seen.

Cholesterolosis and adenomyomatosis are grouped under hyperplastic cholecystoses, which are characterized by proliferation of normal tissue components.

questions.text: The most common etiology of recurrent pancreatitis after an episode of acute pancreatitis is:
questions.solution:

Other causes of recurrent pancreatitis include microlithiasis, hypertriglyceridemia, drugs, pancreatic cancer, pancreas divisum and cystic fibrosis.

questions.text:
Which of the following disorders of bilirubin metabolism leads to predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemia?
  1. Dubin-Johnson syndrome
  2. Gilbert syndrome
  3. Rotor syndrome
  4. Byler disease
questions.solution:
Dubin-Johnson syndrome, Rotor syndrome, and Byler disease are the disorders of bilirubin metabolism which lead to predominant conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia: It occurs either due to a hemolytic process producing excess bilirubin or due to a impaired uptake/ conjugation of bilirubin causing inadequate conjugation.

Causes of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia include: 

  • Increased bilirubin production due to hemolysis
    • Inherited - sickle cell anemia, thalassemia, G6PD deficiency
    • Acquired - paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
  • Increased bilirubin due to ineffective erythropoiesis
    • Iron, cobalamine, and folate deficiency
  • Drugs - Rifampicin, probenecid.
  • Hereditary defects in conjugation - 
    • Criggler-Najjar syndrome (type I and II)
    • Gilbert syndrome

Mixed or predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemia: It occurs either due to impaired excretion of conjugated bilirubin into the bile ductules or due to backward leakage of the bile. 

Familial defects in hepatic excretory function include:

  • Dubin-Johnson syndrome
  • Rotor syndrome
  • Benign recurrent intrahepatic cholestasis (BRIC)
  • Progressive familial intrahepatic cholestasis (FIC)
    • Type 1 - is called Byler disease

Note: Byler disease is a cholestatic disease that presents episodically from infancy. It is due to FIC1 mutation and it can lead to malnutrition, growth retardation, and end stage liver disease during childhood.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used to treat a patient with hypercalcemia due to primary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Glucocorticoids have no effect on the serum calcium concentration in primary hyperparathyroidism and normal individuals. 

They are effective in the treatment of hypercalcemia when associated with the following conditions:

  • Malignancy
  • Vitamin D intoxication
  • Sarcoidosis

Initial medical management of hypercalcemia involves the following:

  • Normal saline (200-500 ml/hour): It is the mainstay treatment to correct dehydration, and titrated to maintain a urine output of >100 ml/hour
  • Pamidronate or zoledronate: These are bisphosphonates and are considered as the drug of choice in primary hyperparathyroidism
  • Cinacalcet: This is a calcimimetic that increases the affinity of the glands to extracellular calcium, thereby decreasing parathyroid hormone secretion
  • Denosumab: This inhibits RANK-ligand, which acts on osteoclasts
  • Calcitonin: This is an activated vitamin D analog that may be used to reduce calcium levels. It should be used within the first 24 hours

Forced diuresis refers to aggressive fluid hydration with loop diuretic administration. Although this is an effective method to reduce calcium levels, it requires careful monitoring for adverse effects like fluid overload, hypokalemia, and hypomagnesia. Due to this reason as well as the availability of more effective treatment modalities, forced diuresis is not preferred any longer.

The definitive management of primary hyperparathyroidism is the surgical removal of the parathyroid gland.

questions.text: Considering the image given, the most common site of airway collapse in obstructive sleep apnea/hypopnea syndrome (OSAHS) is ________
questions.solution:
The soft palate (B in the image) is the most common site for airway collapse in OSAHS. Other sites include the base of tongue (A), lateral pharyngeal wall (C) and/or epiglottis (D).

Note:

OSAHS may be particularly severe in the supine position, due to gravitational forces, and during REM sleep as the neuromuscular output to muscles is particularly low.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about thyroid storm?

choices.text: Symptoms are vomiting, diarrhoea, jaundice and altered mentation
The mortality rate is 10% with treatment
High doses of propranolol decrease  T4 → T3  conversion

questions.solution:
The mortality rate of thyrotoxicosis crisis is almost 30% even with treatment. 

The usual causes for mortality are:

  • Cardiac failure
  • Arrhythmia 
  • Hyperthermia

Related Pearl: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy
  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Stress
    • Infection
    • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
    • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Acute iodine load
    • Amiodarone administration 
    • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
    • Following RAI therapy

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Tachycardia
  • Altered mentation (delirium, psychosis, coma)
  • GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
  • Atrial fibrillation and cardiac failure - most common causes of death

questions.text: The X-ray below is of a patient who recently underwent a bronchoscopy and has complaints of chest pain. Which of the following would you expect in this patient?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows air in the mediastinum, adjacent to the descending aorta and left common carotid artery. Along with the history of the patient, we can arrive at the diagnosis of pneumomediastinum.

Pneumomediastinum:

The main causes of gas/air in the interstices of the mediastinum are

  1. Alveolar rupture, perforation or
  2. Rupture of esophagus/trachea/bronchi,
  3. Dissection of air from the neck or abdomen into the mediastinum.

Clinical Features include severe substernal chest pain(may or may not radiate to neck and arms) & subcutaneous Emphysema over the suprasternal notch.

The examination may reveal subcutaneous emphysema in the suprasternal notch with Hamman’s sign. Chest X-ray confirms the diagnosis. No treatment is usually required but inhaling high concentrations of oxygen will help absorb the mediastinal air. Needle aspiration can be performed if mediastinal structures are compressed.  

Hamman’s sign:

It can be elicited in pneumomediastinum and pneumopericardium. It is a crunching or clicking sound which is synchronous with the heartbeat, best heard in the left lateral decubitus position.

Hoover’s sign is the paradoxical inward movement of the rib cage with inspiration in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

Westermark sign is seen in chest radiographs of patients with pulmonary embolism, indicating focal oligemia.

questions.text: A 15-year-old female presented with complaints of primary amenorrhea to the gynaecology OPD. O/E, she had normal breast development, scanty pubic and axillary hair. Hormonal assays were sent. What is the karyotype of the patient with the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) and the karyotype in this is 46 XY.

AIS (formerly called testicular feminization syndrome) occurs due to mutations in the androgen receptor causing resistance to the effects of androgen. 

Individuals with AIS can have partial or complete AIS. Those with complete AIS have the following features:

  • Female phenotype
  • Normal breast development
  • Blind-ended vagina
  • Absent uterus and ovaries
  • Scanty pubic and axillary hair

The serum level of hormones like gonadotropins and testosterone is variable. They depend on both the degree of resistance as well as the contribution of estradiol to feedback inhibition. 

Most patients present with

  • Inguinal hernias (containing testes) in childhood
  • Primary amenorrhea in late adolescence

Gonadectomy is a recommended course of treatment due to the possible risks of malignancy. The procedure can be scheduled after the individual develops breasts. 

Other options: 

Option A - 45 XO is the karyotype is seen in patients with Turner's syndrome.

Option B - 46 XX is the karyotype for a phenotypically normal female. 

Option D - 47 XXY is the karyotype seen in Klinefelter's syndrome.

questions.text: A man presented with frequent urination and increased thirst. Investigations revealed low urine osmolality and high plasma osmolality. questions.solution:

Central DI is caused by a primary deficiency in AVP secretion which usually results from agenesis or irreversible destruction of the posterior pituitary. It can be differentiated from primary polydipsia with the help of an MRI brain.

questions.text: Which of the following is the leading cause of death in children with diabetic ketoacidosis?
questions.solution:
Cerebral edema is the leading cause of mortality in children with diabetic ketoacidosis.

The osmolar gradient generated due to the high blood glucose level results in water shift from the intracellular fluid (ICF) to the extracellular fluid (ECF) space and leads to the contraction of cell volume. Correction with insulin and intravenous fluids can result in a rapid reduction in effective osmolarity, reversal of the fluid shift, and result in cerebral edema.

Complications of diabetic ketoacidosis include:

  • Cerebral edema – especially in children
  • Cardiac arrhythmia - due to electrolyte imbalance
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
  • Venous thrombosis
  • Acute gastric dilation
  • Acute kidney injury 
  • Intestinal necrosis
  • Acute pancreatitis
  • Mucormycosis

questions.text: A 66-year-old chronic smoker presents with progressive shortness of breath and chronic cough. On examination, he has a barrel chest and has pursed-lip breathing. Hyperresonance and inspiratory wheezes are heard. Pulmonary functions are likely to reveal all of the following, except:

choices.text: Increased diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide

questions.solution:
The given clinical diagnosis is suggestive of COPD and the underlying pathological change is likely to be emphysema. It is associated with a decreased diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO).

Emphysema is defined pathologically as the abnormal and permanent dilation of airways distal to the terminal bronchiole, along with the destruction of their walls. This leads to hyperinflation due to air trapping and impaired diffusion of gases.

Pulmonary function tests in COPD:

  • TLC: Normal or increased
  • FEV1: Decreased (<80% predicted)
  • FVC: Decreased
  • FEV1/FVC: Decreased
  • DLCO: Decreased

Diseases associated with lowered DLCO:

  • Emphysema
  • Interstitial Lung disease
  • Primary pulmonary hypertension

Note - Bronchial asthma is associated with an increased DLCO.

questions.text: The hormone leptin is derived from which of the following?
questions.solution:
Leptin is an adipocyte-derived hormone.

It acts through brain circuits (predominantly in the hypothalamus) to influence appetite, energy expenditure, and neuroendocrine function. High leptin levels reduce appetite and increase energy expenditure.

The arcuate nucleus in the hypothalamus plays an important role in the regulation of appetite.

questions.text: A 47-year-old diabetic man is worried as the skin over his face, neck, and dorsum of hands has turned greyish over the past two months. He also complains of abdominal and joint pain. On examination, gynecomastia and hepatomegaly are noted. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of hemochromatosis. The treatment of choice is the removal of excess iron by phlebotomy.

Phlebotomy is an inexpensive, convenient, and safe method of treatment. In this process, 500 mL of blood is removed 1-2 times weekly which removes 200-250 mg of iron. Weekly phlebotomy should be continued until the serum ferritin level is ≤100 μg/L and every 3 months thereafter. It is contraindicated in severe anemia and hypoproteinemia.

Chelating agents bind to iron to form complexes that get excreted and are the drugs of choice. Drugs such as deferoxamine and deferasirox are commonly used. However, they are less effective and more expensive than phlebotomy.

Liver transplantation is indicated either in end-stage liver disease or in refractory cases.

Supportive management includes avoiding iron-containing substances such as red meat, multi-vitamin tablets, etc. Alcohol should be completely avoided as it can aggravate the disease.
